title.narrative: Fonds de contrepartie de l'ITT - renforcement des capacités de réalisation de recherches de qualité dans les pays à faible revenu
Matching Funds: Building Capacities for Quality Research in Low-Income Countries

description.narrative:
This project will allow the Think Tank Initiative (TTI) to strengthen policy research capabilities and partnerships in low-income countries through matching funds to research centres.
TTI is a multi-donor program that strives to strengthen independent policy research organizations in developing countries. Its objective is to enable these organizations to better provide sound research that informs and influences policy. TTI provides core funding and technical support to help grantee organizations achieve their long-term objectives in the areas of research quality, policy linkages, and organizational performance. In 2011, TTI began offering matching funds to grantee organizations. The funds support efforts to achieve their long-term objectives, and to promote peer learning and collaboration.
Overcoming challenges Low-income countries face two main challenges to produce quality research. The first issue is that data is not always available. When available, it is not always public. When public, the quality is not always good. The second issue is that trained researchers are scarce. The opportunity cost to conduct research is also high.
One grantee organization, Fundación ARU, in struggling with these difficulties, has developed a model designed to produce quality data and train researchers. The model entails: -collecting, cleaning, processing, and harmonizing existing data in order to construct sets of variables to conduct applied research. The data sets are useful for studies on labour market, welfare economics, and program evaluation; and, -recruiting and training young researchers to clean and process raw data, and conduct statistical and econometric analyses.
Virtual training for researchers This project will use this model to build skills and knowledge for four developing-country research centres to conduct quality research. This will be done through a combination of virtual training and researcher exchanges. The centres involved in this project are: -Centre haïtien d'études et de recherches internationales, économiques et sociales (CHERIES), Haiti -Fundación Internacional para el Desafío Económico Global, Nicaragua -Instituto Desarrollo, Paraguay -Foro Social de la Deuda Externa de Honduras, Honduras
More specifically, the project team will: -provide theoretical classes in poverty, inequality, and social exclusion through a virtual training platform; -provide data management, statistical tools, and econometric tools to visiting researchers to allow them to generate and prepare quality data; -explore a joint research agenda with each research centre to make a comparative diagnosis of a social exclusion index for the countries involved in the project; -build a foundation for future collaborative work; and, -start a low-income country research network.
